bestBHT.bht: The order in which Barnabas and Paul are mentioned is significant, reflecting Barnabas' former position of leadership in the Jerusalem church. This ordering validates the historical account and emphasizes Barnabas' seniority. The letter commends Paul and Barnabas for their courage and zeal in spreading the gospel while also highlighting the unity and unanimous agreement of the Jerusalem congregation in endorsing their ministry.

Henry Alford: Paul has generally been mentioned first."
The exception, ch. xiv. 14, appears to arise from the people calling Barnabas Jupiter, and thus giving him the precedence in ver. 12."
But here, as at ver. 12, we have naturally the old order of precedence in the Jerusalem congregation preserved.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Barnabas is put first here, and in :-, on account of his former superior position in the church at Jerusalem.
An evidence this that we have the document precisely as written, as also of the credibility of this precious history.
Marvin Vincent: Barnabas was the elder and better known, and in the church at Jerusalem his name would naturally precede Paul's.

The use of the Greek salutation, and this order of the names, are two undesigned coincidences going to attest the genuineness of this first document preserved to us from the Acts of the primitive church.
Two undesigned coincidences going to attest the genuineness of this first document preserved to us from the Acts of the primitive church.
John Calvin: They commend Paul and Barnabas for their ferventness in zeal and most manlike courage, that they were not afraid to venture or lay down their souls for Christ’s sake.

This is an excellent virtue in a minister of the gospel, and which deserveth no small praise, if he shall not only be stout and courageous to execute the office of teaching, but also be ready to enter danger which is offered in defense of his doctrine.
Therefore, Paul and Barnabas are commended, not because they laid open themselves simply to dangers, but because they refuse not to die for Christ’s sake.
Philip Schaff: The Greek words should be translated here as in Acts 15:22.
It is an indirect testimony to the scrupulous accuracy of the writer of the Acts.
Barnabas in this official letter standing before Paul, because Paul had spent but little time in Jerusalem, whilst Barnabas among the Christians there had long been a known and honoured leader.
Archibald T. Robertson: γενομενοις ομοθυμαδον. On this adverb, common in Acts, see on Acts 1:14. But γενομενοις clearly means that the final unity was the result of the Conference (private and public talks).
The Judaizers are here brushed to one side as the defeated disturbers that they really were who had lacked the courage to vote against the majority.
The verbal adjective αγαπητοις (common in the N.T.) definitely sets the seal of warm approval on Barnabas and Paul.
John Gill: It seemed good unto us, being assembled with one accord...their unanimity was proper to be mentioned, in order to engage a regard to their advice.
Men chosen for this purpose; namely, Judas and Silas.
To testify their approbation of the doctrine and conduct of these two men.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Acts 15:25, the order in which Paul and Barnabas are mentioned is significant. Barnabas is listed first due to his former position of leadership in the church at Jerusalem. This order is consistent with the established precedence in the Jerusalem congregation. Not only does this ordering attest to the credibility of the historical account, but it also highlights Barnabas' seniority and familiarity within the community. This letter not only commends Paul and Barnabas for their courage and zeal in spreading the gospel but also emphasizes the unity and unanimous agreement of the Jerusalem congregation in endorsing their ministry.

In this passage, the placement of Barnabas before Paul is noteworthy, indicating his prior leadership in the Jerusalem church. The order in which the names are listed not only demonstrates the authenticity of the historical account but also emphasizes Barnabas' esteemed position. The letter commends Paul and Barnabas for their fearlessness in sharing the gospel, highlighting their fervent zeal and unwavering dedication. Furthermore, the mention of the assembly's unanimity serves to reinforce the credibility and authority of their endorsement for these two ministers.

The order in which Barnabas and Paul are mentioned is significant, reflecting Barnabas' former position of leadership in the Jerusalem church. This ordering validates the historical account and emphasizes Barnabas' seniority. The letter commends Paul and Barnabas for their courage and zeal in spreading the gospel while also highlighting the unity and unanimous agreement of the Jerusalem congregation in endorsing their ministry.

The prioritization of Barnabas over Paul in this context echoes his former superior position in the church at Jerusalem. This ordering serves as evidence of the accurate preservation of this historical document from the primitive church. The commendation of Paul and Barnabas is attributed to their fervent zeal and unwavering courage in the face of danger, showcasing the virtuous qualities of a minister dedicated to defending their doctrine. The unanimity and approval of the Jerusalem congregation further establishes the credibility and authority of their endorsement.

The order of Barnabas and Paul in this context corresponds to Barnabas' former position of prominence in the Jerusalem church. This order exemplifies the genuine preservation of this historical account and the credibility of the early church's Acts. Both Paul and Barnabas are commended for their fervent zeal and courageous commitment to defending their doctrine. The unity and unanimous approval of the Jerusalem congregation further authenticate the authority and endorsement of their ministry.
